known.p2: This standardized form is very useful for constructing confidence intervals.
known.quiz.title: Quiz
known.quiz.q1: Do you remember what distribution T(X) follows?
known.p3: Because \(\bar{X}_n\) is normal, we have \(T(X)\sim N(0,1)\). Let \(z_\alpha\) be the upper 100α% percentile of the standard normal distribution.
known.p5: This is the 100(1−α)% confidence interval for μ when σ is known.

unknown.quiz.q1: What is the distribution of S(X)?

r.title: Confidence interval in R
r.ex1.title: Example: Generating data
r.ex1.p1: We can simulate a small sample from N(10,1) and view the results:
r.ex1.code:
set.seed(100)
z <- rnorm(n = 10, mean = 10, sd = 1)
print(z)

# install.packages('BSDA')
library(BSDA)
r.ex2.title: Example: Computing CI
r.ex2.p1: Using the built-in t-test, R directly reports the 95% confidence interval:
r.ex2.code:
t.test(x = z)

# One Sample t-test
# 95 percent confidence interval:
# 9.580643 10.383443
# mean of x = 9.982043
